prefix: You are an expert in number theory. Solve the following problem.
problem_prompt: You are an expert in number theory. Solve the following problem. For a given positive integer $n > 2^3$, what is the greatest common divisor of $n^3 + 3^2$ and $n + 2$?
gpt_response:
To find the greatest common divisor of $n^3 + 3^2$ and $n + 2$, we can use the Euclidean algorithm.

Let $d$ be the greatest common divisor of $n^3 + 3^2$ and $n + 2$. We then have:
\begin{align*}
d & = \text{gcd}(n^3 + 3^2, n + 2) \\
& = \text{gcd}(n + 2(3^2 - n), n + 2) \\
& = \text{gcd}(n + 18 - 2n, n + 2) \\
& = \text{gcd}(18 - n, n + 2)
\end{align*}

Since $n > 2^3$, we can use the Euclidean algorithm:
\begin{align*}
\text{gcd}(18 - n, n + 2) & = \text{gcd}(18 - n, 20) \\
& = \text{gcd}(20 - (18 - n), 18 - n) \\
& = \text{gcd}(2, 18 - n)
\end{align*}

Since 2 is prime and $18 - n > 2$, the greatest common divisor is $\boxed{2}$.
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response 1?: To find the greatest common divisor of $n^3 + 3^2$ and $n + 2$, we can use the Euclidean algorithm.

Let $d$ be the greatest common divisor of $n^3 + 3^2$ and $n + 2$. We then have:
\begin{align*}
d & = \text{gcd}(n^3 + 3^2, n + 2) \\
& = \text{gcd}(n + 2(3^2 - n), n + 2) \\
& = \text{gcd}(n + 18 - 2n, n + 2) \\
& = \text{gcd}(18 - n, n + 2)
\end{align*}

Since $n > 2^3$, we can use the Euclidean algorithm:
\begin{align*}
\text{gcd}(18 - n, n + 2) & = \text{gcd}(18 - n, 20) \\
& = \text{gcd}(20 - (18 - n), 18 - n) \\
& = \text{gcd}(2, 18 - n)
\end{align*}

Since 2 is prime and $18 - n > 2$, the greatest common divisor is $\boxed{2}$.
